format

Class Chars2D

  • Object
    • format.Chars2D

  • class Chars2D
extends Object
    We could have many different instances of 2D char arrays that could display different graphics we design. This class encapsulates (hides) the confusion of working with the 2D char array directly elsewhere in our program. This is designed for monochromatic output, so no use of colours in this format package anywhere.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Chars2D(int width, int height)
      Creates an instance that manages a 2D char array for text formatting.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void clear()
      This will fill the 2D char array with backtick ` characters (usually under the tilde ~ in the top-left corner of a keyboard).
      void drawLine(Point2D first, Point2D second, char stroke)
      Avoids using floating-point arithmetic for a faster drawing of a line.
      char get(int x, int y)
      This method swaps the order of the x and y values for us (so we don't have to swap them everywhere else in our code) when we want access to the characters stored in the pixels 2D char array.
      String getFormattedString(int width, int height)
      Prepare to print the pixels 2D char array to output.
      void set(int x, int y, char c)
      Similar to the get method, but assign a char value to an x and y position in the pixels 2D char array.

      • Methods inherited from class Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • Chars2D

        public Chars2D(int width,
               int height)
        Creates an instance that manages a 2D char array for text formatting. You may want to have more than one of these to do some of your own graphics as part of your game (for example, maps, etc). This is not meant for animation, but controlling arrangements of text before printing to the userIO output pixels.
        Parameters:
        width - The number of chars in the horizontal axis of the 2D char array.
        height - The number of chars in the vertical axis of the 2D char array.

    • Method Detail

      • clear

        public void clear()
        This will fill the 2D char array with backtick ` characters (usually under the tilde ~ in the top-left corner of a keyboard).

      • get

        public char get(int x,
                int y)
        This method swaps the order of the x and y values for us (so we don't have to swap them everywhere else in our code) when we want access to the characters stored in the pixels 2D char array. Since pixels stores information temporarily, we do not need to vertically flip anything.
        Parameters:
        x - The horizontal position inside the 2D char array.
        y - The vertical position inside the 2D char array.
        Returns:
        The character stored at position (x, y) in the pixels 2D char array.

      • set

        public void set(int x,
                int y,
                char c)
        Similar to the get method, but assign a char value to an x and y position in the pixels 2D char array.
        Parameters:
        x - The horizontal position inside the 2D char array.
        y - The vertical position inside the 2D char array.
        c - The character to be stored in the pixels 2D char array.

      • getFormattedString

        public String getFormattedString(int width,
                                 int height)
        Prepare to print the pixels 2D char array to output. Note that we are not actually printing yet. This method helps to vertically flip the 2D array as we format output.
        Parameters:
        width - The number of chars in the horizontal axis to print.
        height - The number of chars in the vertical axis to print.
        Returns:
        The complete output string for displaying this char to output.

      • drawLine

        public void drawLine(Point2D first,
                     Point2D second,
                     char stroke)
        Avoids using floating-point arithmetic for a faster drawing of a line.
        Parameters:
        first - The start position of the straight line.
        second - The end position of the straight line.
        stroke - The character used to draw the line.
